data.author: Scott K Logan
data.message:
Fix mpark/variant conditional for MSVC (#77)

This conditional currently evaluates to TRUE when _MSC_VER is not
defined, meaning that __SHOULD_USE_MPARK_VARIANT is 1 for ALL SYSTEMS
except newer MSVC, which is certainly not correct.

Fixes 06e1dbe4ffb1d677a237f00035e323896dc7ffdb

data.author: Dan Rose
data.message:
Change `WIN32` to `_WIN32` (#53)

This seems to have been a typo. The correct macro is `_WIN32` as seen elsewhere in this repo and as per the docs:

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/preprocessor/predefined-macros?view=vs-2019

Possibly responsible for https://github.com/ros-tooling/setup-ros/issues/236

data.author: Dan Rose
data.message:
Bump googletest 1.8.0 -> 1.8.1 (take 2) (#39)

* Bump googletest 1.8.0 -> 1.8.1

Fix build under clang 10 #35

* Update pthread linkage hack to be less fragile

Previously we were editing `internal_utils.cmake` to put `-pthread` after `${CMAKE_THREAD_LIBS_INIT}`. Since GTest switched how they link the thread library (`Threads::Threads` instead of `${CMAKE_THREAD_LIBS_INIT}`), it broke the hack. By using `link_libraries` instead of `set`, targets inside googletest will now be linked properly with pthread.

data.author: Steven! Ragnarök
data.message:
Add CMake option and exported property for memory_tools. (#28)

* Add CMake option and exported property for memory_tools.

This adds a CMake option to explicitly disable memory tools, say to use
ASan instead. It also adds an exported CMake property to describe the
availability of memory tools.

* Disable memory_tools preload on Windows.

* Check memory_tools_is_available before test creation.

Rather than duplicating the specific checks this uses the existing
variable as other packages will use the property which exports this
variable.

* Switches from an `ENable` option defaulting to ON to a `DISable` option
defaulting to OFF.

* Prefixes the option with the package name to avoid potential conflicts.

Signed-off-by: Steven! Ragnarök <steven@nuclearsandwich.com>

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Make sure there is an actual side-effect. (#11)

* Make sure there is an actual side-effect.

To truly keep away the optimizer, we make sure that my_first_function
has an externally-visible side-effect.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>

* Try volatile.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Allocate during initialization. (#10)

We were seeing some errors during MacOS CI in release mode
using the memory_tools.  After doing some local debugging, I found
that it was segfaulting while trying to access a pthread variable
during initialization.  Looking at the code, it looks like it
is possible that the constructor in libmemory_interpose gets
called *before* the static constructor for the recursive_mutex
in unix_common.cpp, leading to this problem.  To work around
this, introduce a new function called complete_static_initialization()
which allocates the recursive_mutex and then sets
initialization_complete to true.  This should be safe from races between
construction and malloc/realloc/calloc on other threads, since those
won't be able to access the recursive_mutex until
initialization_complete is set to true.  It is not safe from races from
multiple copies of __apple_memory_tools_init/__linux_memory_tools_init,
but the rest of the code also assumes that and we don't think it is
possible.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Make sure my_first_function does not get optimized away. (#9)

In 54968fb5b9cc26f72423671ea0504d6876daac9f, I fixed it
so that my_first_function didn't get optimized away in
test_memory_tools.  However, I forgot to check elsewhere, and it turns
out that test_example_memory_tools needs the same treatment.  This
commit does that and makes all of the tests succeed in Release mode.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Make sure that my_first_function does not get optimized away. (#8)

In the nightly builds, the "Release" versions started having
test failures.  After some investigation, I realized that the
problem is that a malloc() followed by an immediate free() is
considered to have no side-effects, so higher optimizations
levels optimize the calls away.  To make sure that my_first_function()
doesn't get optimized away, do a memcpy from an input source
(memset is not enough).

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>
